description: Import template with explicit validation rules for the ExamForge admin tool. Includes one bank and a questions array (1–500 items). Each question supports up to 6 answers; exactly one answer must have isCorrect=true. Fields: bank.name (required), bank.description (optional), bank.year (optional string like 'Year 2'); questions[].topic (optional), questions[].stem (required, 1–1200 chars), questions[].imageUrl (optional, absolute URL), questions[].difficulty (optional: Easy/Moderate/Hard), questions[].mode (optional: Tutor/Timed), questions[].answers[].text (required, non-empty), questions[].answers[].explanation (required—write a concise teaching point explaining why this option is right or wrong), questions[].answers[].isCorrect (boolean, exactly one true).

questions.stem: A 58-year-old with exertional chest pressure relieved by sublingual nitroglycerin presents for evaluation. ECG is normal at rest. What is the most likely diagnosis?

answers.explanation: Typical exertional pain from fixed atherosclerotic narrowing that improves with rest/nitro due to decreased preload and myocardial demand.
Usually progressive or new-onset pain at rest from plaque rupture with thrombosis; would not be predictably relieved only by exertion/rest cycles.
Vasospastic episodes cause transient ST elevation and classically occur at rest/night rather than exertional predictable pain.
Would show troponin elevation and often resting/atypical pain; baseline ECG is often abnormal.

questions.stem: Which intervention improves survival in a patient with COPD and chronic resting hypoxemia (PaO2 ≤55 mmHg or SpO2 ≤88%)?

answers.explanation: Home oxygen for severe resting hypoxemia improves survival and quality of life in COPD.
Provide symptom relief but have not shown mortality benefit.
Reduce exacerbations in some patients but do not confer a clear mortality benefit alone.
Improves exercise tolerance and symptoms but not survival in resting hypoxemia.

questions.stem: A 24-year-old develops ascending weakness 2 weeks after a diarrheal illness. Nerve conduction shows demyelination. Which finding best supports the diagnosis?

answers.explanation: Guillain–Barré shows elevated protein with normal cell count due to demyelination without inflammation in CSF.
Suggests infection (e.g., bacterial/fungal meningitis), not classic for acute demyelinating polyradiculoneuropathy.
Typical of multiple sclerosis (central demyelination), not peripheral demyelination.
CSF WBC count is usually normal in Guillain–Barré; pleocytosis would suggest alternative etiologies.
